subject: RE: [junit] Recursive TestRunner
msgSnippet: Hi J.B., I am not very much worried about the TestCase count. So its fine with me, whether JUnit reports me N tests or 1 test. I hope I got your question
messageBody:
Hi J.B.,

I am not very much worried about the TestCase count.
So its fine with me, whether JUnit reports me N tests or 1 test.
I hope I got your question correctly.

And about Repeated Test Cases, I would like to clarify my requirements
again
I have TestCase classes like
MyTestCase1.java
MyTestCase2.java
MyTestCase3.java
...........
and so on

I have added all of these TestCase classes in one TestSuite as follows

public class MyTestSuite
{
public static Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTest(new TestSuite(MyTestCase1.class));
suite.addTest(new TestSuite(MyTestCase2.class));
suite.addTest(new TestSuite(MyTestCase3.class));
...........................
// and so on
return suite ;
}
}

and I am running this TestSuite like this
C:\> java -classpath <ALL-REQUIRED-JARS-AND-PATH>
junit.textui.TestRunner MyTestSuite

So it will execute all the TestCases, and the setUp() and tearDown()
function makes sure that the fixture
is not executing every time a TestCase is called.
So I have initialization of my application only once, and all the
TestCases run in the same environment.

Now I want to be able to run the same TestSuite again and again, till I
myself don't stop the application.
I looked into the RepeatedTestCase class, but couldn't get it working
for me in my required manner.
Can you give me some pointers on how to use RepeatedTestCase class
As I am not quite clear on that, and couldn't find documentation on
this.

Thanks and Regards,
Rakesh.


-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Tuesday, September 30, 2003 10:11 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Recursive TestRunner


Rakesh wrote:

> >One key question: if you repeat the test n times, is that n tests or
1
> >test? If it's 1 test, then just write the loop in your test.
>
> Hi J.B.,
> As I mentioned, I have a TestSuite, which is having more than 1
> TestCases.
> Thus I can put them in the loop.

I meant a different question. Let me try again.

When you repeat your test code n times, do you want JUnit to report the
entire thing as 1 test or n tests?

> >Either use RepeatedTestCase (part of JUnit) or build the repeated
test
> >suite by hand.
>
> I am looking at RepeatedTestCase now.
> Can you put more light on how can I do the same thing with any other
> way.

That depends on your answer to my clarified question above. If you want
the entire thing to be reported as 1 test, then just put the loop in
your test method. If you want the entire thing to be reported as n
tests, then use RepeatedTestCase.

> I mean if I could modify the TestRunner or some other logic which can
be
> implemented in the TestSuite itself.

Entirely in the TestSuite, just as RepeatedTestCase does.
